case_name: Sahib Singh Dugal v. Union of India

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 55 and 56 of 1965 were filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 55 and 56 of 1965. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights. Gopalakrishnan, for the petitioners  in both the petitions

facts.text: The two writ petitions raise common questions and are dealt with together.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Wanchoo, J. These two writ petitions under Art. 32 of the ,Constitution for a writ of habeas companypus raise companymon questions .and will be dealt with together.

facts.text: Sahib Singh Dugal is the petitioner in Petition No. 55 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: We may set out the facts in one of the petitions  namely Petition 55  in order to highlight the points raised on behalf of the petitioners.

facts.text: Jagdev Kumar Gupta is the petitioner in Petition No. 56 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to referred to the facts in the other petition as they are similar except that in the other case the original arrest took place on December 6 instead of December 8.

facts.text: Sahib Singh Dugal was employed in the Posts and Telegraph Directorate of the Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: Sahib Singh Dugal, petitioner, was employed in the Posts and Telegraph Directorate of the Central Government.

facts.text: Sahib Singh Dugal was arrested on December 8, 1964 and put in jail as an under trial prisoner for an offence under S. 3 of the Official Secrets Act.

anchor.surface_text: He was arrested on December 8, 1964 and put in jail as an under trial prisoner for an offence under S. 3 of the Official Secrets Act, Various remands were taken up to March 11, 1965 in companynection with the criminal case against the petitioner.

facts.text: Jagdev Kumar Gupta was originally arrested on December 6, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to referred to the facts in the other petition as they are similar except that in the other case the original arrest took place on December 6 instead of December 8.

facts.text: Various remands were taken up to March 11, 1965 in connection with the criminal case against Sahib Singh Dugal.

anchor.surface_text: Various remands were taken up to March 11, 1965 in companynection with the criminal case against the petitioner.

facts.text: Eight other persons besides Dugal were involved in the case under S. 3 of the Official Secrets Act, including Jagdev Kumar Gupta.

anchor.surface_text: It appears the besides Dugal, eight other persons were also involved in the case under S. 3 of the Official Secrets Act, including Jagdev Kumar Gupta petitioner in petition No. 56 of 1965.

facts.text: On March 11, 1965, the Deputy Superintendent of Police made a report to the court that all nine persons might be discharged as sufficient evidence for conviction could not be discovered.

anchor.surface_text: On March 11, 1965, the Deputy Superintendent of Police who was apparently in-charge of the investigation made a report to the companyrt to the affect that all the nine persons involved in that criminal Case might be discharged as sufficient evidence for their companyviction companyld number be discovered during the investigation.

facts.text: The magistrate discharged all nine persons including the petitioners on March 11, 1965, and they were released from jail that evening.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the magistrate discharged all the nine persons including Sahib Singh Dugal and Jagdev Kumar Gupta petitioners and they were released from jail that very evening.

facts.text: Immediately after Sahib Singh Dugal came out of jail, he was served with a detention order under R. 30(1)(b) of the Defence of India Rules passed by the Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately after Sahib Singh Dugal came out of the jail, he was served with an order under. 30  1   b  of the Defence of India Rules  hereinafter referred to as the Rules , This order was passed by the Government of India and provided that Dugal be detained

facts.text: The detention order provided that Dugal be detained to prevent him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the defence of India, public safety and India's relations with foreign powers.

anchor.surface_text: This order was passed by the Government of India and provided that Dugal be detained in order to prevent him from acting in an manner prejudicial to the defence of India, public safety and Indias relations with foreign powers.

facts.text: Dugal was arrested and detained in the Central Jail, Tihar, New Delhi in accordance with the order under R. 30(4) of the Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Dugal was then arrested and detained in the Central Jail, Tehar, New Delhi in accordance with the further order of the Government of India under r. 30 4  of the Rules.

facts.text: The detention order was passed on the same date as the report for discharge, March 11, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: So on March 11 a report was made to the magistrate that the petitioners should be discharged as there was number sufficient evidence for their companyviction and on the same date the order for their detention was passed under the Rules.

facts.text: The detention order was served on the petitioners immediately after their release from jail.

anchor.surface_text: Further it was served on the petitioners immediately after their release from jail.

facts.text: The petitioners had been in jail for about three months before the detention order.

anchor.surface_text: In the present cases it is true that the petitioners had been in jail for about three months before the order of detention was made against them.

facts.text: The material in respect of the activities of the petitioners ranged over a period of two years before the date of detention.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact, the affidavit on behalf of the Government of India is that the material in respect of the activities of the petitioners ranged over a period of two years before the, date of detention

facts.text: Petitioners contend that the detention orders are illegal in view of Rameshwar Shaw v. District Magistrate, Burdwan decision.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioners before us is two-fold. In the first place they rely on the decision of this Court in Rameshwar Shaw V. District Magistrate, Burdwan 1  and their case is that in view of that decision the order of their detention

facts.text: Petitioners contend that the detention order is mala fide because criminal proceedings were dropped due to lack of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In the second place, it is urged that the order of detention is mala fide in the circumstances of the case and therefore should be set aside.

facts.text: Union contests the petitions, stating Rameshwar Shaw has no application and no mala fide intention.

anchor.surface_text: The Union companytests the petitions and urges that Rameshwar Shaws case  1  has numberapplication to the present cases and that there was numbermala fide intention in making the orders of detention.

facts.text: In Rameshwar Shaw case, detention order passed on February 9, 1963 and served on February 15, 1963 while in jail.

anchor.surface_text: Rameshwar Shaw was ordered to be detained by an order passed on February 9, 1963. This order was served on him on February 15, 1963. At that time he was in Burdwan jail.

facts.text: Rameshwar Shaw was in jail in connection with a pending criminal complaint for indefinite time.

anchor.surface_text: He had been in that jail for time past in companynection with a criminal companyplaint pending against him. Therefore, both when the order was passed and when it was served on Rameshwar Shaw, he was already in jail

facts.text: The judgment was delivered by Wanchoo, J.

anchor.surface_text: Gopalakrishnan, for the petitioners  in both the petitions  Ganapathy Iyer and R. N. Sachthey, for the respondent  in both the petitions . The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Wanchoo, J.

facts.text: Gopalakrishnan appeared for the petitioners in both petitions.

anchor.surface_text: Gopalakrishnan, for the petitioners  in both the petitions  Ganapathy Iyer and R. N. Sachthey, for the respondent  in both the petitions

facts.text: Ganapathy Iyer and R. N. Sachthey appeared for the respondent in both petitions.

anchor.surface_text: Ganapathy Iyer and R. N. Sachthey, for the respondent  in both the petitions . The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Wanchoo, J.

facts.text: Executive authorities decided to drop the criminal case against petitioners for want of sufficient evidence.

anchor.surface_text: But there is a significant difference in the present cases, namely, that the executive authorities had decided that the criminal case against the petitioners companyld number succeed for want of sufficient evidence and applied for the discharge of the petitioners.

facts.text: Court holds that Rameshwar Shaw case does not apply to the present cases.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the petitioners cannot get advantage of the decision of this Court in Rameshwar Shawscase   on the facts in the present cases.

facts.text: Court holds that the orders of detention were not mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: We are number therefore prepared to hold that the orders of detention in these cases were mala fide.

issues.text: whether the orders in the present cases are covered by the decision of this Court in Rameshwar Shaws case and should therefore be set aside

anchor.surface_text: We shall first companysider whether the orders in the present cases are companyered by the decision of this Court in Rameshwar Shaws case 1  and should therefore be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the second place, it is urged that the order of detention is mala fide in the circumstances of the case and therefore should be set aside.

issues.text: whether the past activities of the petitioners are proximate in point of time to justify the order of detention

anchor.surface_text: detention is made generally in the light of the evidence about the past activities of the person concerned. But these past activities should ordinarily be proximate in point of time

arguments.claim: The orders of detention and their service are illegal in view of the decision in Rameshwar Shaw v. District Magistrate, Burdwan, entitling petitioners to release

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioners before us is two-fold. In the first place they rely on the decision of this Court in Rameshwar Shaw V. District Magistrate, Burdwan 1  and their case is that in view of that decision the order of their detention and the service of hat order are illegal and they are therefore entitled to release.

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts differ materially: in Rameshwar Shaw, indefinite custody; here, authorities decided to discharge from criminal case before imminent release, so not covered by ratio decidendi

anchor.surface_text: In the second place, it is urged that the order of detention is mala fide in the circumstances of the case and therefore should be set aside.

arguments.court_reasoning: Dropping criminal prosecution for lack of evidence does not imply mala fides; preventive detention can be justified by wider past activities even if criminal conviction not possible

arguments.claim: Rameshwar Shaw's case has no application to the present cases

arguments.claim: There was no mala fide intention in making the orders of detention

anchor.surface_text: The Union contests the petitions and urges that Rameshwar Shaws case  1  has no application to the present cases and that there was no mala fide intention in making the orders of detention.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: inally intended to prosecute the petitioners under s. 3 of the Official Secrets Act and when the authorities were unable to get sufficient evidence to

arguments.court_reasoning: Sequence of dropping prosecution and detaining does not prove mala fides; justified by two years of monitored activities warranting preventive measures

arguments.claim: Rameshwar Shaw does not apply because petitioners were to be discharged from criminal custody, unlike indefinite jail time there

anchor.surface_text: In the present cases it is true that the petitioners had been in jail for about three months before the order of detention was made against them. But there is a significant difference in the present cases, namely, that the executive authorities had decided that the criminal case against the petitioners could not succeed for want of sufficient evidence and applied for the discharge of the petitioners.

arguments.claim: Second detention order valid even if served in custody after revoking prior one, distinguishing Rameshwar Shaw (citing Godavari Shamrao)

anchor.surface_text: This matter was again considered by this Court in Smt. Godavari Shamrao v. The State of Maharashtra.  1  That was a case where a certain person had been detained under the Defence of India Rules. Later, this order was revoked and another order was passed to remove some technical defects.

arguments.claim: Past activities of petitioners are proximate enough to justify detention despite three months prior jail time

anchor.surface_text: As was pointed out by this Court in Rameshwar Shaws case 1  detention is made generally in the light of the evidence about the past activities of the person concerned. But these past activities should ordinarily be proximate in point of time in order to justify the order of detention.

arguments.claim: Dropping criminal case under Official Secrets Act for insufficient evidence does not make subsequent detention mala fide if based on broader past activities over two years

anchor.surface_text: The next contention on behalf of the petitioners is that the order is mala fide. The reason for this contention is that it was originally intended to prosecute the petitioners under s. 3 of the Official Secrets Act and when the authorities were unable to get sufficient evidence to obtain a conviction they decided to drop the criminal proceedings and to order the detention of the petitioners.

holdings.text: the ratio decidendi of Rameshwar Shaws case will not apply

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the ratio decidendi of Rameshwar Shaws case 1  will number apply, for the authorities had decided to drop the criminal case and ask for the discharge of the accused. Then they considered whether there was justification for the detention of the petitioners under the Rules and decided to, detain them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts differ materially as executive authorities decided to discharge petitioners from criminal case due to insufficient evidence before passing and serving detention order immediately upon release, unlike indefinite custody in Rameshwar Shaw

holdings.text: the petitioners cannot get advantage of the decision of this Court in Rameshwar Shaws case on the facts in the present cases

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the petitioners cannot get advantage of the decision of this Court in Rameshwar Shaws case   on the facts in the present cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Past activities proximate despite three months jail time; material over two years considered; distinguishes Rameshwar Shaw and follows Godavari Shamrao where fresh detention valid post-revocation even in custody

holdings.text: It cannot be said that the conduct of the petitioners before this period of three months is not proximate enough to justify an order of detention based on that conduct

anchor.surface_text: In the present cases the petitioners had been in jail for only three months before the order of detention was passed. It cannot be said that the conduct of the petitioners before this period of three months is number proximate enough to justify an order of detention based on that conduct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Activities ranged over two years before detention; three months custody does not render prior conduct remote per Rameshwar Shaw principle on proximity

holdings.text: We are not therefore prepared to hold that the orders of detention in these cases were mala fide

anchor.surface_text: We are number therefore prepared to hold that the orders of detention in these cases were mala fide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dropping criminal prosecution under Official Secrets Act for lack of conviction evidence does not imply mala fides; preventive detention justified by broader past activities over two years warranting prevention of prejudicial acts

precedents.citation: Rameshwar Shaw V. District Magistrate, Burdwan 1

anchor.surface_text: Rameshwar Shaw V. District Magistrate, Burdwan 1 and their case is that in view of that decision the order of their detention and the service of hat order are illegal and they are therefore entitled to release.

precedents.case_name: Rameshwar Shaw v. District Magistrate, Burdwan
precedents.cited_proposition: where a person was already in jail for an indefinite length of time in connection with a criminal case pending against him it would not be possible for the authority to come to the conclusion that such a persons detention is necessary in order to prevent him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the public safety etc.
precedents.cited_holding: the authority ordering detention could not legitimately come to the conclusion that the detention of the person was necessary to prevent him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the public safety etc. for in coming to that conclusion the authority had to be satisfied that if the person is not detained, he would act in a prejudicial manner and that inevitably postulates freedom of action to the said person at the relevant time.

precedents.citation: Smt. Godavari Shamrao v. The State of Maharashtra. 1

anchor.surface_text: Smt. Godavari Shamrao v. The State of Maharashtra. 1 That was a case where a certain person had been detained under the Defence of India Rules. Later, this order was revoked and another order was passed to remove some technical defects.

precedents.case_name: Smt. Godavari Shamrao v. The State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: the second order of the State Government after it had decided to revoke the earlier order was perfectly valid so far as the time of making the order was concerned and its service on the detenu who was detained not as an under trial or as a convicted person could not be assailed, and the case of Rameshwar Shaw was distinguished.
